items.synopsis: Deputy NSW Coroner Elizabeth Ryan hands down her findings after an inquest into the disappearance of Melissa Caddick — the Sydney woman who went missing in 2020.

image.altText: Composite image of a blonde haired woman on the left and a middle aged man on the right

image.altText: Stan Grant makes statement on his last episode as host of ABC's Q+A

image.altText: A PwC logo on the side of a building.

items.synopsis: The federal Finance Department tells consulting firm PwC to "stand down" any staff who knew about Treasury tax leaks from working on any existing or future government contracts.

image.altText: A screenshot shows Tina Turner as Auntie Entity in a mesh outfit, spreading her arms in front of followers.

image.altText: Montage of Tina Turner pictures

image.altText: A Tasmanian devil in the bush

items.synopsis: The proponent of a contentious wind farm on a Tasmanian island has been asked to come up with a plan to compensate for the loss of hundreds of hectares of Tasmanian devil habitat.

title.children: Tasmanian devil habitat latest hurdle for planned wind farm

image.altText: Man with Tasmanian giant freshwater crayfish.

image.altText: A computer keyboard lit up in red.

items.synopsis: Australia has joined the United States and other Five Eyes cyber agencies to identify China as the culprit behind recent cyber attacks targeting "critical infrastructure" in the US.

title.children: Australia joins intelligence partners to blame China for US infrastructure cyber attack

image.altText: Chee Kit Chong and wife Angie Yeh Ling Liaw smile at a restaurant

items.synopsis: It is alleged Chee Kit Chong and wife Angie Yeh Ling Liaw exercised coercive control over the woman, limited her movements and physically assaulted her at their home in Melbourne's south-west for 10 months in 2022.

title.children: Melbourne couple arrested for allegedly keeping woman as slave at their suburban home

image.altText: Ron speaks in front of a huge US flag as people cheer.

items.synopsis: Ron DeSantis has officially entered the 2024 presidential race after his formal campaign announcement was marred by technical glitches on Twitter.

title.children: Ron DeSantis's presidential bid announcement hit with tech glitches as #DeSaster trends on Twitter

image.altText: A man with a dead pig

items.synopsis: Five police officers were hurt in the incident involving an allegedly stolen truck, with one officer still in hospital in a stable condition.

title.children: Man faces court over alleged attempted murder of police officers near Toowoomba

image.altText: Tina Turner belting into a microphone. She has short, curly blond hair and red lipstick. She's wearing a black lace chemise.

items.synopsis: The American-born singer left a hard-scrabble farming community to become one of the top recording artists of all time.

title.children: Tributes pour in for 'Queen of Rock'n'roll' Tina Turner

image.altText: An adult hoses down a group of clothed children who splash the water as they sit on a street.

items.synopsis: There are fresh warnings about the soaring heat across south and south-east Asia as a UN report warns global temperatures are very likely to hit records in the next five years.

title.children: Brutal heat across Asia prompts warnings from climatologists of what's to come

image.altText: A hand pointing a TV remote towards a TV, which displays the Netflix logo

items.synopsis: Netflix is making account holders pay to share their passwords with people they don't live with, heralding a new phase in the evolution of streaming services. Let's unpack what this means for the future of entertainment.

title.children: Netflix is cracking down on password sharing. Is the golden age of streaming services over?

image.altText: Mojib Rahman stands on a rooftop looking out to the horizon.

items.synopsis: Mojib Rahman went from scam victim to "money mule", as he tried to recover his lost funds. Now his bank has apologised for the way it handled his case.

title.children: This retiree googled 'money mule' after his bank told him he was one. What he found made him 'very nervous'

image.altText: view from beach looking out to ocean

items.synopsis: The federal government has offered $22 million to settle a class action over PFAS contamination relating to the community's ability to live on, or conduct cultural activities on its land.

title.children: $22 million offer to settle PFAS contamination in Wreck Bay Aboriginal community

image.altText: Piles of giant logs lying next to a forest of Australian native trees.

items.synopsis: Victoria's decision to bring forward the end of native timber harvesting was meant to bring certainty, but it has not eased the pain in timber communities.

title.children: Timber town workers 'in tears' as Victorian government deals final blow

image.altText: A young women with long blonde hair holds her child in front of balloons

items.synopsis: Over the past two years, the Newcastle LGA has accounted for over 8 per cent of the state's alleged murders, according to NSW crime figures.

title.children: 'Cluster' of alleged murders in Newcastle five times NSW average

image.altText: Peter Dutton Budget reply

items.synopsis: The number of Liberals now supporting the Voice is difficult to discern and the mood among those few who are still publicly on board has turned to dismay following Peter Dutton's full-scale denunciation of the Voice proposal, which went much further than many were expecting, writes David Speers.

title.children: Two body blows for Liberals who disagree with Dutton on the Voice

image.altText: picture of flood affected area in Guam

items.synopsis: The powerful typhoon lashes the Pacific island with winds of up to 169 kilometres an hour, bringing heavy rain and tearing down trees, walls and power lines.

title.children: US territory of Guam in the Pacific smashed by Typhoon Mawar

image.altText: An aerial shot of water pools and mangroves at sunrise in an otherwise arid landscape

items.synopsis: The Indian Ocean travels underground and reappears 17 kilometres inland at a unique WA wetland that has so far been overlooked as a site of significance.

title.children: Ecologist reignites push to better protect wetlands on salt mine lease

image.altText: julie inman grant speaks at a press conference

items.synopsis: Reports of "sextortion" to the eSafety Commissioner triple in the first quarter of 2023, with victims most likely to be young men.

title.children: Instagram and Snapchat are the most-used platforms for 'sextortion', with young men most at risk

image.altText: A photo highlighting the word losses on the ASX share market boards.

items.synopsis: The Australian dollar slides with shares following after a "risk-off" drop on Wall Street. The Australian Energy Regulator announces a default price jump for residential and small business customers. Follow the day's events on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Dollar drops, shares slide as interest rate and debt ceiling worries spook traders

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares fell 0.88 per cent, to 7,150 points, after noon, with miners continuing to record losses amid weaker iron ore prices. BHP shares fell 1.18 per cent to $42.32 while Rio Tinto dropped 1.2 per cent. Treasury Wine Estate shares fell 5.88 per cent after chief executive Tim Ford said sales would be down overall across the group by 2 to 3 per cent. Silicon Valley Bank owner First Citizens Bank says it will cut 3 per cent of its workforce, after its collapse earlier this year. The bank, which has been described as once "the hearts and lungs" of lending in Silicon Valley, was taken over by First Citizens, a North Carolina lender. The bank was one of many US regional banks to face pressure and was left with big debts when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates earlier in the year. However, the acquiring bank has now announced layoffs, with about 500 positions, or 3 per cent of its workforce, set to be eliminated. First Citizens Bank chief executive Frank Holding said these job cuts would primarily affect 'select' corporate roles.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian shares down, SVB owner lays off nearly 500 staff

children.content: Australian shares fell 0.88 per cent, to 7,150 points, after noon, with miners continuing to record losses amid weaker iron ore prices.
BHP shares fell 1.18 per cent to $42.32 while Rio Tinto dropped 1.2 per cent.
Treasury Wine Estate shares fell 5.88 per cent after chief executive Tim Ford said sales would be down overall across the group by 2 to 3 per cent.
Silicon Valley Bank owner First Citizens Bank says it will cut 3 per cent of its workforce, after its collapse earlier this year.
The bank, which has been described as once
"the hearts and lungs" of lending in Silicon Valley
, was taken over by First Citizens, a North Carolina lender.

props.alt: outside SVB bank branch in the US

children.content: SVB bank collapsed earlier this year
(AP Photo: Jeff Chiu)
The bank was one of many US regional banks to face pressure and was left with big debts when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates earlier in the year.
However, the acquiring bank has now announced layoffs, with about 500 positions, or 3 per cent of its workforce, set to be eliminated.
First Citizens Bank chief executive Frank Holding said these job cuts would primarily affect 'select' corporate roles.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Unlike most other central banks, South Korea's could be cutting rates soon. The Bank of Korea board voted to keep its policy rate unchanged at 3.50 per cent, as both inflation and economic growth eased. The central bank started raising interest rates in August 2021 to tame inflation, well before the world's other major central banks, and had raised them by a total of 300 basis points through January this year. Capital Economics senior Asia economist Gareth Leather said: "we don't think it will be long before the [Korea's] central bank starts cutting interest rates". "With inflation falling back, the economy struggling and the housing market downturn deepening, we think the BoK will start loosening monetary policy in August, earlier than when others are expecting. " "The main reason we think the central bank will start loosening policy soon is the weakness of the economy. GDP grew by just 0.3 per cent in Q1 following a 0.4 per cent contraction in the final quarter of last year. He said pressures were also continuing to ease. "The headline rate has fallen from a peak of 6.3 per cent in July 2022 to 3.7 per cent in March, which is the lowest reading in over a year." "Overall, we are expecting 75 basis points worth of rate cuts this year, with the first cut likely to be in August." He noted that in contrast, most other analysts are expecting either very modest cuts, or for interest rates to be left unchanged this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bank of Korea hold rates steady, but rate cuts next?

children.content: Unlike most other central banks, South Korea's could be cutting rates soon.
The Bank of Korea board voted to keep its policy rate unchanged at 3.50 per cent, as both inflation and economic growth eased.

The central bank started raising interest rates in August 2021 to tame inflation, well before the world's other major central banks, and had raised them by a total of 300 basis points through January this year.
Capital Economics senior Asia economist Gareth Leather said: "we don't think it will be long before the [Korea's] central bank starts cutting interest rates".
South Korea's central bank may soon cut rates
(ABC News)

"With inflation falling back, the economy struggling and the housing market downturn deepening, we think the BoK will start loosening monetary policy in August, earlier than when others are expecting. "

"The main reason we think the central bank will start loosening policy soon is the weakness of the economy. GDP grew by just 0.3 per cent in Q1 following a 0.4 per cent contraction in the final quarter of last year.
He said pressures were also continuing to ease.
"The headline rate has fallen from a peak of 6.3 per cent in July 2022 to 3.7 per cent in March, which is the lowest reading in over a year."
"Overall, we are expecting 75 basis points worth of rate cuts this year, with the first cut likely to be in August."
He noted that in contrast, most other analysts are expecting either very modest cuts, or for interest rates to be left unchanged this year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares opened lower, with the ASX down 0.67 per cent to 7,165.3 at 10.37am. The lower opening in Australia followed market sell off across Europe and the US. Treasury Wine Estate was the worst performing stock, its shares tumbled 5.3 per cent after chief executive Tim Ford said sales will be down overall across the group by 2 to 3 per cent. The major banks also opened lower. At 10.30am CBA was trading 0.6 per cent lower, Westpac lost 0.7 per cent, ANZ dropped 0.7 per cent and National Australia Bank fell 0.5 per cent. The Australian dollar is down slightly fetching 65.42 US cents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower; Treasury Wine shares tumble

children.content: Australian shares opened lower, with the ASX down 0.67 per cent to 7,165.3 at 10.37am.
The lower opening in Australia followed market sell off across Europe and the US.
Treasury Wine Estate was the worst performing stock, its shares tumbled 5.3 per cent after chief executive Tim Ford said sales will be down overall across the group by 2 to 3 per cent.
The major banks also opened lower.
At 10.30am CBA was trading 0.6 per cent lower, Westpac lost 0.7 per cent, ANZ dropped 0.7 per cent and National Australia Bank fell 0.5 per cent.
The Australian dollar is down slightly fetching 65.42 US cents.
